text: Airbnb or Hotel in Rome ?? Thoughts ?

Depends. First time in Italy? How long will you be in Rome? For a short stay, I'd recommend a hotel since they will likely have a front desk and can help with info/
transportation/
luggage storage on days you check in/out. They will also likely have breakfast right there at the hotel. For a long stay (at least 5 days) an Airbnb might make more sense. You'll likely get a bigger space for the same or less money, and will have a fridge to keep food/drinks, and a microwave and cook top. You might also get a washing machine, which is handy if you've been traveling awhile and Rome is your last stop.

Has anyone used Withlocals.com
For tours?

comments.comment_text: We booked tours with them and are leaving in a couple of weeks. The reviews look good..

Hey all! We just finished the first leg of our trip in Venice. We took 2 tours with Withlocals. The first day was with Valentina for a romantic your choice tour (it is our 15 year anniversary so we requested that the tour guide hire a photographer and we also requested a gondola ride as well) we wanted to see the local markets and shopping that Venice had to offer as well for our romantic tour. The second day was our food tour we had Giada who took us to all the best local traditional foods of Venice we tried the fried mozzarella sandwich, gnocchi, gelato, cheeses and pastries.

I think the best thing about withlocals is that it is intimate. You book a guide and they cater to you. You are not surrounded by strangers and can go off the beaten path if you ask.

We asked to go to a different spot and Giada took us. We asked Valentina which restaurant to try and at the end of the tour she walked us to the restaurant.

Both guides were awesome and I highly recommend withlocals.

Hope this helps!! 🙂

text:
Florence:

Staying at Hotel Rapallo; a family owned and run hotel of 19 rooms. I would say this is “Downtown” and very close to Cathedral Santa Maria Del Fiore’ aka (Duomo). There is also a small park nearby. The staff and rooms are great they offer excellent service.

Tip #1- if you don’t want to pay for a Taxi be prepared to walk, walk, walk. You can rent vespas/scooters, electric bikes but I’ve never been so scared to drive anywhere. Watch-out as a pedestrian because every driver is in a hurry. Honking appears to be a priority lol.

Tip #2- If your walking learning you way around quickly or have a paper map, YES I said paper. I purchased an international phone plan but many times the maps wouldn’t load and I got lost and very confused. It is July and so very hot.

Tip #3- Make sure to drink plenty of water and have a refillable water bottle. There are some free water fountains but they are few and far between. Water in restaurants is not free.

Tip #4- if you do take a taxi try to use your google map as we quickly learned some drivers like taking the long long long way around.

Tip #5- Be cautious of pickpockets, and beggars they sometimes work together to distract you. But most importantly Have fun, enjoy the scenery and take in all that this beautiful place has to offer.

comments.comment_text: I visited Venice for two days off a cruise ship
We found Florence to be an amazing walking city. Four days and no taxis. Once you have your bearings it was great! We logged 20k+ steps a day.

Any recommendations
on where to eat?

Beautiful but work it seems... hearing that from everyone... think other countries may be a bit better, sad to think that...
A second thumbs up for Hotel Rapallo - staff, rooms, and breakfast.

Tip#4. How did you stop being taken advantage of? Show them the google map and route you wanted to take to your destination so they could not take a longer way? Just curious. I have heard Taxi drivers in NY do the same thing!

text: FIRST DAY SUGGESTIONS BEFORE CHECK-IN? Wonderful travelers, our flight arrives 8am from the US and our Airbnb checkin is 4pm (Milan, October, my husband and myself). I know we'll be tired but don't want to waste our first day. How have you spent your first day before check-in? Grazie!

If you can leave your luggage somewhere, it’s a great time to wander in the area, check out menus of restaurants, get your bearings.After we landed in Venice we did a guided tour, and when we arrived in Rome we did a hop on hop off bus tour until we could check into our hotels.

text: Travelling 4 days in Rome in August what are the must thing to see/do, we've booked collesseum

comments.comment_text: Vatican if you can

- Vatican Museum
- Pantheon
- All the main squares such as Piazza di Spagna, PiazzaNavona, etc…)
- Fori Imperiali
- Fontana di Trevi
- Castel Sant’Angelo
- Villa Borghese
- And all the city 🤣
Vatican is a must see!
Cooking class, Under Trevi Fountain, catacombs

We’ve been to Rome several times before but one of the things we did this time around, mainly for our kids who found it way too hot to walk around and see the main attractions, was a tour of Rome by golf cart! It was great and we got to see all the main attractions and do all the photo ops with the kids without the complaint of walking too much or being too hot. Also, the Haunted Tour which starts off at Castel Sant’Angelo just before 8 pm is great if you’re into that kind of thing.
When visiting the Vatican are there any tips and is it only one day for the Vatican?
Also the Jewish ghetto

ROME POSSIBILITIES
+Day 1 (1/2 day only): Strolling in the Trastevere district, Basilica di Santa Maria in Trastevere + dinner
+Day 2: Piazza Navona, the Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, Sant’Ignazio di Loyola church, + strolling on Via dei Coronari + dinner in the Campo de’ Fiori
+Day 3-4: Advanced booking is necessary!
a. Vatican (on a pre-booked, small-group, guided tour) (3h30m)
b. Galleria Borghese (2.5 hrs). Book TODAY!
c. Colosseum (2-3 hrs.) Book through Coop Culture (the official website for the colosseum). Third-party sites frequently cancel.
Other:
+ Spanish Steps
+ Monument to Vittoria Emanuele II. Take the elevator to the top for the views.
+ Strolling in the historic center (e.g., Campo de’ Fiori) and dinner
+ Palazzo Colonna, Saturday morning only, with reservation. Still privately owned. Spectacular grandeur.
+ Galleria Doria Pamphilj: art museum in a palace. Must-see: the OPULENT Galleria degli Specchi (Gallery of Mirrors)
+ Golf cart tour

We just had four days in Rome too 😍 arrival day we had quick photos at the Trevi fountain and Spanish steps (both heaving) and went to the church at the top of the steps, day two Colesseum then refreshment break then Roman Forum and Palatine Hill, rooftop bar at night, day three Vatican museum breakfast tour and st Peter's Basilica including climbing the cupula and then walked home via Trastevere and stopped for multiple gelatos and an art gallery and church. Final day was three art gallery visits (including Borghese gallery which was amazing the tour was fantastic) and walked through the gardens. it was an amazing experience ❤️

Yes def book Galleria Borghese. We booked 2 weeks before and got a 3-5pm slot. Children need to be booked too but are free. It cost £34 for family if 4. They only let about 150 visitors in for each session. It’s in the Villa Borghese park which provides some shade plus has a zoo. We are in Trastevere at the moment. Last full day for us in a 3 bed Airbnb with aircon. Has been a godsend in this heat and our teenagers have loved the stroll round Trastevere at night and the amazing choice of restaurants
The Trevi fountain glimmering in the sunlight and lit up at night was our favorite.
Pantheon and piazza navona
St Peters Basilica near Vatican is breathtaking. You must go inside.
The Catacombs was so cool!!!

Santa Maria Maggiore is another beautiful basilica to visit has relics of St Luke and a shrine with pieces of the manger in it. Also
note the Vatican is closed on a Wednesday morning so all the tours head to the Colosseum so it does get really busy. We popped into random churches and were amazed by the works of art we saw.

text: My husband and I plan to go to Venice, Florence and Rome next October 2024. Is that a good time of year? Should we booked everything, tours, and trains before hand? Any recommendation tours regarding Venice how do you get a private taxi, etc.

I booked my first trip of 2 weeks myself and had everything organized. Just took some time and effort. But very very doable.

Just gotta start with what you want to see and do. All the big tourist things, winery tour, etc. do you enjoy a lot of walking etc

The only thing I let the travel agent do was flights. The rest I did, accom, trains , buses etc. That way we aren't completely locked in except for our travel days moving to our next destination. I choose train times ahead though, say 2 departure times so we don't have to be regimented.
We can also change the itinerary right up til we leave if we want to.

October is an excellent time! Big crowds should be gone, the summer heat is gone, but most things should still be open. Just check online to make sure.
There’s so much to do and see in those areas, I don’t think you’ll need a travel agent. However, I would suggest tours for things like the Vatican, or the big museums so you don’t have to wait in long lines, and get right to the pieces you are most wanting to see.
I recommend Walks - their guides are just so full of info! A real “must”!

https://
www.walksofitaly
.com/
Joining this group is a great step. Keep up on the posts and you will get sooo many ideas. And questions answered.

October is perfect because you avoid the hot weather of the summer.

I think you can easily plan yourself.

If you want to move by train check Italo or Trenitalia.

Don’t make train reservations in advance, they’re prone to numerous delays. Early October is lovely, most tourists are gone and it’s pre rainy season. No need for a travel agent as they will direct you to touristy places and events.
When Florence, you must take the local bus to Fisiole where the panoramic views of the city are spectacular. Rome is huge, diverse and overwhelming. You need to pick a central location and take day trips from there. I recommend Trastevere .
Venice is a one time experience. I suggest staying in Murano, a small island in Venice. Make sure you pack already worn in comfortable shoes, function over fashion. You will get rain, but it won’t be cold. Ask locals for family owned restaurants off the touristy zone. Go to open Mercados for food and snacks and leather product to cut down on restaurant expenses. Make sure you have a mini fridge for your wine and snacks😍
Also make sure your banks are notified as your atm withdrawals and card charges will look like fraud and will be declined. Don’t carry excessive cash and never wear a backpack unless it’s facing forward. Theft is no joke. Download a translator on your phone to make communication easier and Italians enjoy your efforts to speak their language even though in large cities, they speak English. Take copies of all your documents such as credit cards, atm cards, passports, drivers licenses etc and leave the originals in a safe. But only a safe in your room, not the front desk. Never let anyone safekeeping your passports… ever, such as the front desk. Enjoy!
Would not recommend Neos airlines which we used. No app, website does not function…maybe they are aiming for travel as ancient Romans would have
October is a good time for Italy.

I booked everything for 7 seniors this past September for a full month in Italy. Easy to do. Tackle one city at a time. Book guides with excellent reviews. ItalyEU Tours. Walks of Italy are very good.
Perfect time of the year, I went last October and loved it!

Yes, perfect time to go. You can do it yourself if you’re detail oriented and enjoy that sort of thing. I would say plan but don’t over plan. You want to enjoy yourself not run yourself into the ground. So give yourself days to wander and just explore. Don’t book every minute. Have a wonderful time! ￼

I was in Rome last October and it was very crowded; more than our other visits…6 before this one. This year, we did two cruises in Apr/May, then stayed in Sorrento for 8 days in May…the entire coast was packed. I tell you this because you need to be prepared. Just get out as early as possible to enjoy this time of the morning without the crowds! Those places like Dolomites, Castelrotto, Bolzano or smaller towns, IMHO, are the very best to enjoy, so do not stay in Sorrento or Positano, but smaller areas close by. Rome is Rome, but add a smaller and more authentic Italy to your trip. Research is your best friend! Do not plan too much either, as you need time to just enjoy! My very first trips to Italy were my favorite because it wasn’t so overrun with us tourists. Venice ride the Vaporetta and see Venice at its best. Specially late 8nbthe afternoon when the colours on the houses, change, r magic. Try to sit right up the front for views. Ride the length of Grand Canal, get off, cross 5he canal and ride it opposite direction.

text:
Venice:

Absolutely stunning, pictures don’t come close:
Tip #1- I recommend a water taxi to get you and all your luggage directly to your hotel or you will be dragging your luggage over countless bridges and cobblestones streets
Tip #2- However beautiful this place is it is not stroller/wheelchair friendly.
Tip #3- Wear comfortable shoes you will absolutely walk everywhere (no one cares if your shoes match your outfit) blisters are no joke on cobblestones streets.
Tip #4- Gondola rides are amazing but be smart about getting your tickets ahead of time, rates can be high if you don’t book ahead.
Tip #5- Get Euros, merchants prefer you pay with Euros. Most do accept Credit/Debit cards but for bargain prices the Euro will get you great prices. You can find conversion table’s online.

Finally
Tip #6- Packing light is the best recommendation I should have listened to, I usually travel only with a carry on but I listened to a friend and over packed. I have found so many beautiful clothes/accessories and great and affordable prices. You really should pack light if you don’t have direct service from airport to Hotel.

text:
I gathered my post about less popular places in Tuscany was helpful so I’d gladly share some suggestions about Veneto for people who’d like to visit more in the region besides Venezia.

I’d start with Verona where I hail from.

Verona: Soave, Valpolicella (wine tasting, nature check San Floriano, San Giorgio Ingannapoltron, marble quarries),Valeggio sul Mincio (check Parco Sigurtà), Borghetto sul Mincio (very romantic old water mills), Lessinia Natural Park, Lazise, Peschiera del Garda ( if with kids maybe check out Gardaland amusement park if into that) and if you want something different try “Festa del riso”in Isola della Scala (famous for Vialone Nano rice cultivation one of the best rice varieties for risotto, one of the dishes we love in Verona; try risotto all’isolana/al tastasal)

Riviera del Brenta (between Venezia and Padova, summer destination of the dogi, Casanova, D’Annunzio, Byron are among a few of the notorious visitors of the area; palazzos and breathtaking villas, great for hiking, bike rides)

Asolo

Bassano del Grappa

Possagno (Canova’s gipsoteca)

Padova (Colli Euganei great for hiking, biking and wines, Arquà Petrarca (Petrarca’s home)

Delta del Po (birdwatching, hiking and trying eel based dishes)

Vicenza (Basilica Palladiana, Teatro Olimpico, Giadino Salvi and other treasure s by Palladio)

Marostica (medieval town with the famous ”chess piazza”, and castles)

Chioggia could be a nice stop before getting to Venezia.

Treviso (Tomba Brion and the town itself is very pretty, ofcourse prosecco)

Ciao!

We will be arriving at FCO on oct 15 8:40 am from chicago and we are heading to vatican hoping to get there by noon to attend 12 pm mass.
Will taxi or train better.
Family of 4 here. With 2 9 year old.
Pls help. Thanks!

comments.comment_text: Train from the airport will be a good option
Taxi is easy and not expensive.
Uber
Hire a car. Have to ask, What are you planning on doing with your luggage?
Taxi is faster but there’s a fix rate from the airport 50 euros
I’f you won’t catch 12 pm there is 5 pm mass too
Get a driver. We just tried making it to a service from our flight on Pentecost. They drop rose petals from the Pantheon on Pentecost. But flight got delayed 7 hours at O'Hare so we missed it.
Train, take you right there.
Remember you need to allow for enough time to drop your luggage off at your hotel or storage facility. I don’t know if you will make the noon mass if you only have three hours.

The easiest is not always economical. But arranging a car service is by far the best and but not the most economical. You will probably need a van. A driver will meet you inside and help with your luggage and you don’t have to wait on the line for a taxi. It is a set price, but there may be an extra charge for a stop to check your luggage.

text: I suffered a catastrophic lower limb amputation in April ,and trying to figure out if I can make my Italy trip in September .I will be using a wheelchair and a walker (for bathrooms etc ) and while no prosthesis yet ,I am hoping to make the trip ! Anyone out there experienced Italy while in a wheelchair ? I am going to Rome and Tuscany region .

comments.comment_text: I have not seen many wheelchairs but that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t come. You’ve fought too hard through a life changing and difficult experience to not come. So here is what I do know…Italy does not have ADA. So make sure you research your hotels well. Many do not have elevators and have very narrow doorways. But there are hotels that have renovated and are much more accommodating so you should still be able to find something. Any tours you book (especially Tuscany)make sure they have capability for transporting a wheelchair. Hopefully someone on this page has better advice and experience. Have a fantastic trip 🍷🇮🇹

Years ago my partner, in wheelchair, and I traveled Paris and Rome. Everyone was so very kind. The Swiss Guards at the Vatican were super helpful. Sooo...I say GO! Just make sure your hotel has a lift.
I agree with double checking on accommodations to be careful, but other than that? Go. It will help soothe your soul.

I visited Italy in a wheelchair and crutches ( my third trip to Europe, first to Italy). We saw Rome/Florence/
Pompeii/Amalfi.

You can absolutely do it-just requires some planning!
We were able to find hotels with elevators without too many issues. Bathrooms in the hotels were not necessarily accessible, depending on what accommodations you need, but I was able to make it work.
All the sites we visited were generally accessible, or at least "doable" We booked all private tours, as they could be more flexible without worrying about other folks.
For transportation,
we used private cars, occasional taxis and trains. If you contact Sala Blu( a group that has offices in the train stations that assists people with disabilities to access the trains) it makes the trains SUPER easy.
That's just high level stuff that comes to mind. Feel free to contact me if you have any questions I can try to help with. It can absolutely be done, if you keep in mind that since they don't have the same ADA laws we do, and you'll need to be more flexible, you'll be ok!!

If you take any trains in Italy, check out Sala blu or blue, which is a service for those with mobility issues or are handicapped. They will even give you a wheelchair and transport you to your car of the train. It’s a very good service, reliable and free.

We just got back from Rome last week. My dad walks with a cane. We didn’t get him a wheelchair, and at times we did wish we had. I saw a couple of wheelchairs in various places (Vatican, Colosseum, etc.). I think as long as you’re taking one or have a rental set up, you’ll be ok. It’ll be hard because Rome is an old city built way before ADA, but doable for sure. Safe trip!
I also believe that the website wheels of the world will provide you with a Hotel suggestions in Italy that have elevators, and or or wheelchair accessible

You have gotten this far; you can do it!!! and as others have said, it only requires a bit of planning. We just returned from our 12 day dream vacation to Rome, Florence & Venice. Our son needed to take and use his wheelchair. We normally plan trips ourselves, but for a variety ￼of reasons, we used a travel agent who well researched all accessible excursions, hotels etc. She was great, but forgot to tell us about Sala-blu- an extraordinarily
helpful train service for persons with mobility issues. I'll provide link for you. They will get you on & off trains with no worries on your part. You just need to make reservations at least 24 hours in advance.
Pushing our son in a wheelchair in Rome- on cobblestones-ga
ve us a workout in the heat, but no complaints and so worth it. The Coliseum has an elevator!!! I'll be honest, we splurged for some private tours as we wanted to ensure our son could hear ever thing and that we would not be rushed in a group setting. We did that with. day trip to Siena, a winery and Pisa. All areas where we used the wheelchair with ease.
People were so kind and helpful to us- from hotel staff to total strangers. There are good people in this world and nothing should stop you from creating a beautiful trip. Best of luck.
https://
www.rfi.it/en/
for-persons-with
-disability/
sala-blu.html

So sorry for your loss. I just came back from 2 weeks in Italy. While I am not in wheelchair, I have serious back and knee issues which affect mobility. I was worried about getting around. I took golf cart tours in Rome. Florence has them too. Lots of taxis and private transfers. Hotels with elevators. Do you planning ahead and you should be fine. Forge ahead and enjoy your trip.
In Rome specifically me and my friend both commented on how accessible it was. Lots of stairs lifts/ramps etc. Hope you can make the trip and have a wonderful time x

My hubby did not suffer an amputation BUT he did tear his meniscus a few days prior to arriving. He insisted on making the trip. He used a cane and was limited, particularly in Rome on the uneven terrain and crowded areas. We still managed to do the Vatican (with skip-the-line option), a golf card tour of all the significant landmarks (it’s our 12th time in Italy so we had already seen most of the sights before) but this golf cart tour was incredible & so worth it, especially for someone with limited mobility and in the scorching heat. We had booked the catacombes for the kids to see and I ended up taking them myself as hubby had too difficult of a time going up and down all the steps.

It’s doable but definitely look for alternatives to walking tours or regular tours.
There are companies like www. sagetraveling . com that cater to people with needs similar to yours.
If you’re interested in the coloseum, our tour guide was able to accommodate someone who needed an elevator.
We just came back from Europe, it was so challenging even without wheelchair, I wouldn't do it, sorry...honest opinion

Oh no. Sorry to hear that. I hope you make out well on your travels.
Heal well!
Check hotel. Some have elevators that only accommodate luggage and 1 person. Make sure wc accessible
I have no experience or information - just wanted to say how sorry I am about your catastrophic injury!!! Wishing you good health and a safe trip!

I am a amputee and have traveled to Tuscany nine times and Rome three times. Message me any questions. The cobblestones will wear on your back. The energy will lift your spirit and you will love Italy. I go the first week in November. It is fresh olive oil time and I love the fall.
I am here now and have seen several people in wheelchairs. Even the hop on hop off tour buses have places for wheelchairs
Go. You'll still be in 🇮🇹 ❤️. Sounds like you've earned some time there and there is great advice from this group. You got this, Bless you.🤗

Hooray for you for forging ahead. My husband was diagnosed with Guillain Barre a few weeks before we left for fourteen days. He used a wheel chair for the bigger museums (and finally in Venice). We parked him in great cafes across from the Coliseum and on several squares (Siena, Lucca,)when it was just too difficult. He enjoyed people watching and eating pastries! Museums were great for wheelchairs- elevators, special entrances.
He finally agreed to a wheelchair to get around Venice- and then strangers from all over the world carried the chair while he used a cane on the stairs of bridges.
Wishing you a wonderful trip and a grand adventure!

I have been to Rome 2x with my partner at the time in a wheelchair... train staff are amazing and we were able to source hotels that catered... cobblestones were a problem. ... my husband's legs kept bouncing around and we secured his legs to the chair... rookie mistake ... the ties cut into his legs...
However we saw everything we wanted.. skipped lines at the Vatican and St. Peter's and other sites... had a blast
Don't let it stop you, I'm sure you will be fine, a lot of Rome is flat, and some of the Tuscan towns should be ok too, the cobblestones will be hard but still try and go and enjoy❤️
You can do it ♥️👊🏻

Last time I went to Italy I was able to hire a foldable mobility scooter in Rome! It got delivered to the hotel I was staying at. Just charge the battery overnight, and away you go. I toured all over Rome, Tuscany and Venice no problem. My Italian travel guide arranged for the coach driver to load it in the back with suitcases.

This is the most positive thread I have ever seen since joining this group !!!! I think you have an awesome amount of good advice here! Though the museums and churches are important- there is nothing like sitting in a square and enjoying a glass of wine and enjoying the sights! I learned about Sala Blu and having a much older husband with mobility issues I am delight to have got that information for us.
Have an amazing time- a trip to Italy is just what the doctor ordered!!!!! Buon viaggio i🇮🇹

Go for it! In our hotel in Bologna alone there were two people with casts in wheelchairs. And in every city we have visited we have seen people in chairs. Venice has chair accessible water taxis and gondolas.

text:
Where is the best place to celebrate new year 2024 in north Italy?
Milan, Florence, Venice or somewhere else

Hi everyone, I have a question regarding travelling solo to Italy. I am a 53 year old single female and in my circle no one can’t travel with me for one reason or another, I have been waiting now for over 2 years for anyone to coordinate their vacations with me with no luck. I have been single for over 10 years (by choice) and I enjoy it so much,आणखी that I don’t mind doing anything or travelling alone at all 😃. For this reason, I feel like I am missing out on wonderful travel experiences and I don’t want to wait any longer! My question is, how safe is for a single woman to rent a car and travel alone all over Italy? Thank you.

comments.comment_text: Hi. Look at the cummari.com … but i live here in Palermo with my man. We came 2 months ago so we Are living here, i feel safe when i am going around alone❤️ just contackt me on pm if u want.
I'm 74 and have traveled solo for many years. Italy is my favorite country for solo travel. Very safe as long as you're smart and use common sense. Have a wonderful trip!
join the facebook group Girls LOVE Travel® lots of great posts about solo female travelers!

You will be perfectly safe. I love my solo trips.
I leave the driving in Italy to my husband when we travel together, on my own I use trains, lots of walking, taxis.
If you are going to drive, get an International Driving permit and read up on Italian road rules, especially the ZTLs. Every city/town has areas restricted to locals only and if you drive in there you will be ticketed.
It's quite safe. Just common sense like anywhere in the world. Pick-pockets in very crowded tourist places. Avoid deserted streets late at night, etc.

I went to Italy for the first time on my own at 21, and I felt safe 🙂 so much so, that I have been back on my own since, and plan on going again!

Personally I’ve never rented a car, but have used their public transport, and haven’t had any issues!
Just do it. I gave up waiting on someone to travel with. Like going by myself. Can do and see what I want to do and see!!!!✈️
I'm 66 and just spent a month in Italy. Safe as any other place if you're sensible and attentive. I used trains though and did 1 full day tour from Rome to Amalfi and Pompeii. Loved it.

My daughter is 40 and just returned from 3 weeks in sardinia then flew to Florence then train to nice. All single and loving it. She felt safe and was out at night. Just have to aware of uour surroundings like u would in any city n
I did it several years ago. No problems
I went to Italy last year, 2 months all by myself I am 60 plus and it was the best of times. I used the train mostly but did drive Tuscany. The way I see it life is short ai am not waiting on anyone!
Maybe do partially a tour. A few days on your own then join the tour and a few days after the tour or move on for a week somewhere else after the tour. Have a look at Albatross Tours.
Perfectly safe. But use common sense. You will love my Italy and you will return!

I just got back from 3 weeks solo travel - did a tour in Italy but was on my own for several days there, then also on my own in London and Paris. Just be aware if your surroundings, have a good GPS on your phone. I’d recommend train rather than driving. Travelling solo was very liberating and fun. I’d do it again. Have fun.
On FB, search solo travelers; there are many groups. On this post alone many tips and even somebody who needs a travel buddy. Good luck. It will work out!!
I’m 42 and have been traveling solo in Europe for years. Italy is a wonderful place for solo travel. I feel safer traveling in Europe than I do back home.
Just went last month solo and though I didn’t rent a car I felt safe everywhere I went.

You can go on a cruise to Italy !
We went this year and there were a lot of singles . Oceania cruise actually arranged for single to meet !

I have a friend at Donnakirkland.c
om that does worldwide trips. She takes groups. She and group just got back from Thailand. Going to London in October. She is planning an Italy or an Italy/Greece trip. There are many singles that travel with her. My husband and I did a 16 day Italy with her a few years ago. She lets you get your money’s worth!!! Check out her website.
Google crime Stas for italy a d compare them with your home country's. Ic your from the US then the crime figures will, be considerably higher than Italys. Just go and enjoy yourself

Go for it. I’ve traveled in Italy by myself by train. As long as you look at it as an adventure and not a holiday. Some things won’t go to plan and that’s ok. A bad day in Italy is still better than a good day at work. Enjoy it and go with the flow.

I didn’t hire a car but I did travel solo for a week in June, pisa, cinque terre and lucca. Public transport is fantastic in Italy, felt safe in all of those places, I’m 58 and one of the best hols I had. Even tried a hostel! Go for it

I’m traveling with my daughter but we have felt safe everywhere at every hour!!!! Sure even the locals tell you be careful with pickpocketers when you ride the bus but our imagination goes wild as to relate it maybe to a mugging….DEFINI
TELY NOT THE CASE!!!! Do travel don’t miss out🙏
Go with a tour group. Travel with people who may become friends/future travel buddies and you get alone time when you want it.

Girl .. I went to Paris alone for this very reason. I had been divorced awhile - had just been through a very sad event concerning a grandchild/
cancer - I needed to get AWAY. Got a smokin' deal and no one could go. I went by myself and it was Wonnnnnnderful (well, except for once retired for the night - this was long before affordable international internet). Anwyay .. GO ... Italy is Beautiful. Don't rent car for in Rome, Florence etc - parking nightmares. But outer areas should be fine (I personally would NOT drive along the coast near Sorrento to Almafi -- crraaazzzzy scary and better to hire a driver and enjoy the view!!). JUST GO ....
Just like any modern country in the world
I’ve traveled alone for years and absolutely love it. I have never felt unsafe traveling on trains, buses or walking at night.

I have also travelled solo through Italy - driving on my own and using public transport. It is a wonderful, liberating, empowering experience, and an opportunity to connect with other world travellers and locals.
Depending on where you're planning to visit, a car is just not worth the expense or the challenge. For example, if you're planning in spending a few days in Florence, Rome, or Naples ... either explore on foot, or use public transport if you're wanting to go a little further ... from Florence you can reach Lucca, or Pisa, or La Spezia by train, for a day trip.
The Amalfi Coast - use public transport - very little parking available for non-residents and parking garages are costly.
Tuscan countryside - you need a car to give you the freedom to explore, stop where you choose, find those gems along your journey.
Puglia - as per Tuscany.

As others have mentioned, just always be aware. Don't leave yourself vulnerable though at night on the streets of Spaccanapoli, for example.
Small tours are great to join in and learn the history - there are any number online you can pre-book, depending on your interests.
Also pre-book skip-the-line tickets for main attractions, or you will spend your days queuing!
Have the best time ever!

I’d advise trains and other public transport. Parking is very difficult often, pedestrian islands, trying to navigate and drive, signage, etc. Have a wonderful time in a very beautiful, friendly country.
Do it!!!🥰
I don’t know the answer but have done ireland alone buses and trains…..
Please go and enjoy every moment. You will have a wonderful time.
Go and enjoy. Go with a tour

Why not go with a group that specializes in solo tour? GoAhead is one such company, but there are several others. Google them and read the reviews. You will have the benefits of a planned trip, companions, and safety in numbers…and you make some new friends. 🤗

to be fully in control of what you see, where you go, when you go, how long you stay is the ultimate indulgence for a memorable holiday. you will be looked after and probably have more experiences than if you were part of a group.

Florencetown! You meet at their office in Florence and take a van with a small group (in our case it was my husband and I plus 3 other couples). We hiked some of the cliffside terraces, had time to explore 3 of the 5 villages, and had a delicious lunch done family style with our group. Our guide was fantastic!
Yes be prepared to hold your breath and never want to leave
Take a private tour.
Viator has a great one.

From Florence we took the regional train to La Spezia where we stayed for 2 nights. Then we took the local train to Cinque Terre to visit the 5 villages. we hop on hop off the whole day. Amazing experience.
Following

You can do an easy day trip too. Train to le spezia and 6 min cab ride to the boat point. And do a boat tour. You get it easily. You can hop on and off the boat to explore villages ( 2-3 are enough) and take a train back from Monterosso.
And avoid get your guide tours
Villa Valentina is the best! Great hosts, great breakfast, great everything. Check it out for sure

text:
When you purchase travelers insurance, do you buy it for each flight you’re taking and each hotel you’re staying at? It seems to be offered separately for each flight I book & each hotel stay (1 in Rome & 1 in Florence).

TIA!! :)

comments.comment_text: this must be an American thing as UK you pay for your whole duration? ie. 7 days you get u 7 days travel insurance that covers for the whole time you are there..
I booked policy for land, sea and air all together.
You purchase it to cover all legs of your trip. You can also purchase a policy that covers all travel within a calendar year.
You arrange for date your trip begins to the date you get home. If travelling to more than one country check your policy covers all

I get it per trip....for instance my current insurance for 5 months worldwide includes all medical including medevac and other flights home e.g. for surgery, family member coming if I'm more than 10 days in hospital, emergency trips home, cancelled accommodation for most circumstances, lost or stolen luggage, lost property, dental repairs etc etc.
You can get singe or multi trip insurance. I get a 1 year policy.
I insure flights hotels.
Do you travel more than once a year? I get annual insurance on that covers all my trips. I believe it’s about $200 a year.

In 35 years of traveling outside the US I’ve never bought insurance. Oct 2022 on a cruise I needed some Medication saw the ship Dr paid $200 for visit an meds. I filed a claim with Medicare they paid me the allowed amount of $65. 👍
Mine covers me from the first flight date till I land back at home and it covers medical, transport and everything in between ...
I purchase an annual travel plan thru Allianz. Covers all trips during the year. $450 - covers my husband and me.

Make sure you read the whole policy… we bought Airbnb insurance and our flight was cancelled and we missed a night at the Airbnb and they would not cover the night since the airline cancelled due to operational because they only would cover delays due to weather, mechanical, or a strike. It wasn’t that much money but we did try to get that back since we bought the extra insurance in case something like that happened.
Always buy independent travel insurance.
